answer_html: This last relation tells us that b=n+a=5.5.
answer_latex: This last relation tells us that b=n+a=5.5.
hints_html:
The left Riemann sum of a function \(f\) over the interval [a,b] with n intervals is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{aligned}\]

with \(\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

The midpoint Riemann sum of a function \(f\) over the interval [a,b] with n intervals is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1/2)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{aligned}\]

with \(\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

The right Riemann sum of a function \(f\) over the interval [a,b] with n intervals is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^{n} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{aligned}\]

or

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x\end{aligned}\]

with \(\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}\)
hints_latex:
The left Riemann sum of a function \emph{$f$} over the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} with \emph{n} intervals is given by

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
\end{align*} with
$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

The midpoint Riemann sum of a function \emph{$f$} over the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} with \emph{n} intervals is given by

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1/2)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
\end{align*} with
$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

The right Riemann sum of a function \emph{$f$} over the interval
\emph{{[}a,b{]}} with \emph{n} intervals is given by

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^{n} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
\end{align*}

or

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
\end{align*} with
$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$
hints_raw:
The left Riemann sum of a function ''&fnof;'' over the interval ''[a,b]'' with ''n'' intervals is given by
:<math>
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
</math>
with <math>\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}</math>



The midpoint Riemann sum of a function ''&fnof;'' over the interval ''[a,b]'' with ''n'' intervals is given by
:<math>
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1/2)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
</math>
with <math>\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}</math>



The right Riemann sum of a function ''&fnof;'' over the interval ''[a,b]'' with ''n'' intervals is given by
:<math>
\sum_{k=1}^{n} f(a+k\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
</math>

or

:<math>
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} f(a+(k+1)\Delta x)\cdot\Delta x
</math>
with <math>\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}</math>
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
There are multiple correct answers to this problem. The following is but one of three possible interpretations:

This is a left Riemann sum from 1.5 to 5.5 with \(n=4\) rectangles.

If we look at our left endpoint formula in the hint, we realize that

\[\begin{aligned} a&=1.5\\ n&=4\\ \Delta{x}&=\frac{b-a}{n}=1.\end{aligned}\]

This last relation tells us that b=n+a=5.5.

There are multiple correct answers to this problem. The following is but one of three possible interpretations:

This is a midpoint Riemann sum from 1 to 5 with \(n=4\) rectangles.

We can recognize this by writing

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=0}^3f(1.5+k)=\sum_{k=0}^3f(1+(k+1/2))\end{aligned}\]

which is in the form of our midpoint formula in the hint if we take

\[\begin{aligned} a&=1\\ n&=4\\ \Delta{x}&=\frac{b-a}{n}=1.\end{aligned}\]

This last relation tells us that b=n+a=5.

There are multiple correct answers to this problem. The following is but one of three possible interpretations:

This is a right endpoint Riemann sum from 0.5 to 4.5 with \(n=4\) rectangles.

We can recognize this by writing

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=0}^3f(1.5+k)=\sum_{k=0}^3f(0.5+(k+1))\end{aligned}\]

which is in the form of our right endpoint formula in the hint if we take

\[\begin{aligned} a&=0.5\\ n&=4\\ \Delta{x}&=\frac{b-a}{n}=1.\end{aligned}\]

This last relation tells us that b=n+a=4.5.

statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Put your answer in the box provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Fill in the blanks with right, left, or midpoint; an interval; and a value of \(n\).

\(\sum_{k=0}^{3}f(1.5 + k)\cdot 1\) is a _________ Riemann sum for \(\displaystyle f\) on the interval [____ , ____] with \(\displaystyle n =\) ______.
